content: recipe for a hooded granny square cardigan by insertinnergeek designs due to the way you need to fit squares together to fit the wearer it is hard to make a traditional pattern with a variety of sizes this is just the process i followed to make my cardigan please note that unlike my paid patterns this recipe is not properly graded for sizes tested or proof read so i am making it available for free if you have any questions or spot any typos please feel free to email me at insertinnergeek@gmail com please do not reproduce or sell this recipe but do feel free to pass on the link to my payhip or ravelry shops or to link to and follow my instagram or facebook https //payhip com/insertinnergeek https //www ravelry com/designers/kristen-salzer-frost https //www instagram com/insertinnergeek/ https //m facebook com/insertinnergeek recipe for a granny square cardigan by insertinnergeek designs step 1 choose your squares this method should work with any kind of granny square but the smaller the squares the better you can adjust the fit of your cardigan i chose to use a traditional granny square with 4 rounds as i liked the way the colour changes of my yarn looked at that size the yarn i used was bramble dk by king cole in the logan berry colourway i used the recommended 4mm hook once you are happy with your square measure how long a side is this is the square size mine was 4 page 2 recipe for a granny square cardigan by insertinnergeek designs step 2 wearer measurements the measurements i took were ● bust/chest ● shoulder tip to shoulder tip across the back ● shoulder to hem for however long you want the cardigan to be ● shoulder to wrist ● around the upper arm ● hood measurement from shoulder across the top of the head to the other shoulder step 3 estimate the number of squares you will need the shape of the garment is all made up of rectangles which i am referring to as panels while estimating how many squares you will need be aware of how stretchy your squares are and double check when you have made and joined some row of squares see step 5 fit check back panel the width of the back panel should be as close to the shoulder to shoulder measurement as possible but making it too small will restrict movement my measurement was 21 and 5 squares gave me a back panel that was 20 across this works but i wouldn t want it any smaller work out the number of squares you need to make your back panel your shoulder to shoulder measurement -1 or larger this is the back panel width shoulder to shoulder -1 / square size rounded up to next integer e g 20-1 /4 = 4 75 therefore back panel width is 5 squares the length of the back panel is based on the desired shoulder to hem measurement
